video.title: Code a Discord Bot with Python - Host for Free in the Cloud
video.description:
Learn how to code a Discord bot using Python and host it for free in the cloud using Repl.it. 
🚨Note: At 16:43, Replit now has a new method for environment variables. Check the docs: https://docs.replit.com/programming-ide/storing-sensitive-information-environment-variables

Along the way, you will learn to use Repl.it's built-in database and create a Discord bot that uses webhooks to connect with GitHub.

Need help with this tutorial? You can ask questions here: https://forum.freecodecamp.org/

This course was developed by Beau Carnes.

🔗 Online code editor: https://repl.it
🔗 Discord Home Page: https://discord.com/
🔗 Discord Developer Portal: https://discord.com/developers/applications

💻 Python server code for bot: https://gist.github.com/beaucarnes/51ec37412ab181a2e3fd320ee474b671
💻 Full code on repl.it: https://repl.it/@BeauCarnes/Encourage-Bot

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (01:18) Creating a Discord Server
⌨️ (01:52) Creating a Bot User
⌨️ (06:05) Starting a Project in Repl.it
⌨️ (09:33) Coding a Basic Discord Bot
⌨️ (20:14) Improving the Bot
⌨️ (33:35) Using the Repl.it Database to Store Bot Settings
⌨️ (56:09) Testing the Bot
⌨️ (58:42) Creating a Web Server for the Bot
⌨️ (1:03:36) Connecting Uptime Robot So Bot Runs Continuously
⌨️ (1:05:21) Creating a GitHub Discord Bot Using Webhooks

Special thanks to Repl.it for providing a grant that made this course possible.

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Ωuntrouble
topLevelComment.text:
"TypeError [ClientMissingIntents]: Valid intents must be provided for the Client."
Seen this error? of course you have
As of discord.js v14 you need to add intents into the client function
what i mean is, instead of just putting
const client = Discord.Client();
you need to put some parameters into the Client() function, which are the intents that we're talking about
const client = new Discord.Client({ intents: ["Guilds", "GuildMessages"]});
Look at all those intents
they should fix the issue
(note: you may need to add more intents for more features)
not my comment, will edit the comment to credit the original person
also can yall bring this to the top of the comment section tyy

import discord

client = discord.Client(intents=discord.Intents.default())


@client.event
async def on_ready():
  print('Logged in as {0.user}'.format(client))


@client.event
async def on_message(message):
  if message.author == client.user:
    return

  if message.content.startswith('hello'):
    await message.channel.send('Hello!')
    print('Send Hello!')


client.run(os.environ['bot_key'])

topLevelComment.author: Gouda
topLevelComment.text:
IDK if this helps anyone starting AFTER the slash commands update
You will need to do a lot of extra steps now
1. You have to enable message intent for the bot and the code
How? For bot, go to discord dev portal, go to bot, and scroll down, you will see it
For code, type 
intent = discord.Intents.default()
intent.members = True
intent.message_content = True

client = discord.Client(intents=intent)

then continue on as the video, hope this helps if u are stuck.

replies.author: Anonymous404
replies.text: @Justin first, the computers they host the scripts on are pretty limited, and as such it rate limits your amount of requests you can send. This means that if too many people are using your bot, it will get temporarily stopped. The second is the fact that all scripts are completely public unless you get the paid version, which means pretty much anyone can see pretty much anything you do. The tokens are stored online, which means when replit is compromised, your bot may be at risk. Another thing is their use of shared ips among users. In the context of bots, it means that if someone near you is banned for spamming requests/banned from discord, your bot will be stopped too because it’s on the same ip. Lastly, it doesnt support hosting the bot 24/7. You need to use a third party website to stop replit from closing the program. This adds another margin for error.

topLevelComment.author: Ayush Mehra
topLevelComment.text:
For those who are using IDE or any other desktop tool and getting error :

Raise keyerror(key) from None
Keyerror: 'TOKEN'

USE dotenv module, first  install by using :- pip install python-dotenv
Command in your shell
Then import:
from dotenv import load_dotenv

After importing load_dotenv from dotenv
Initiate your load_dotenv() class before  importing toke by typing:
load_dotenv

Now use os.getenv function to get your token :
Token=os.getenv('TOKEN')
client.run(Token)

Hi guys,

When i launch that  in jupyter i got a RuntimeError: Cannot close a running event loop ?

import discord
import os
 
client = discord.Client()
%env TOKEN= XXXX

@client.event
async def on_ready():
    print("We have logged in as {0.user}".format(client))


@client.event
async def on_message(message):
    if message.author == client.user:
        return

    if message.content.startswith('$hello'):
        await message.channel.send("Hello looser!")


client.run(os.environ['TOKEN'])

topLevelComment.author: Roxsanne Patel
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone wondering what to do now that replit changed their secret variables (16:43), do the following:
Click on the Padlock icon on the left of the page
In the key box, give it a name (in this case, it would be "token")
In the value box, enter your bots secret token
Add the secret
Go back to your python file, and make sure you have "import os" at the start
Before the "client.run..." line, add "my_secret = os.environ['token']
And in the client.run line, type "client.run(os.environ('token'))

replies.text:
you just put the quotation mark in a wrong place 
yours is : 
print('We have loged as {0.user}.'format(client))

it should be like that,  notice the quotation mark (AND THE UPPERCASE C) : print('We have loged as {0.user}'.format(Client))

so your code will be :

import discord

import os



Client = discord.Client()



@Client.event

async def on_ready():

	print('We have loged as {0.user}'.format(Client))



@Client.event

async def on_message(message):

	if message.author == Client.user:

		return



	if message.content.startswith('$hello'):

		await message.channel.send('hello')



Client.run(os.getmain.enviromen('TOKEN'))

topLevelComment.author: Random
topLevelComment.text:
this tutorial is so bad

instead of:

import discord


client = discord.Client()


@client.event
async def on_ready():
    print('Online')


@client.event
async def on_message(message):
	if message.author == client.user:
		return

	
if message.content.startswith('$hello')
		await message.channel.send('Hello!')


client.run('your token here')

use this instead its much more organized:

import discord
from discord.ext import commands


client = discord.Client(command_prefix="$")


@client.event
async def on_ready():
    print('Online')


@client.command()
async def hello(ctx):
    await ctx.send('Hello!')


client.run('your token here')

but to use it you also need to add from discord.ext import commands

replies.text:
its because that feature has been removed and you have to instead use the secrets feature on the left side of your bar. Once you create your secret by the name TOKEN as your key and your actual token as the value, input this:

my_secret = os.environ['TOKEN']
client.run(os.environ['TOKEN'])

topLevelComment.author: Ishan Choudhary
topLevelComment.text:
for people getting an error on os.environ and os.getenv. Works both on repl.it and local machine. So create a secret key in repl.it, or create .env in your local machine. Then go to the shell tab in repl.it or go to the terminal on your local machine.
Type: 
pip3 install --upgrade python-decouple

Then restart your editor, if you are on you local machine. Go to the file holding the discord bot code. Type:

from decouple import config
client.run(config('TOKEN'))

topLevelComment.author: Fabian
topLevelComment.text: This is a pretty old tutorial but i just wanted to let ya know that the quotes part is absolute garbage. Dont do it like this! DONT use requests with discord.py because requests is synchronous and discord.py works asynchronous. When making a request this will block the asyncio event loop and the bot (and every other async function) will stop working in this time. Use aiohttp instead, its async aswell and wont block the event loop

topLevelComment.author: SaibopCUR
topLevelComment.text:
FOR ANYONE WHO CANNOT DO THE .ENV FILE BECAUSE IT DISPLAYS AN ERROR:

On the side bar on the left of the screen there is a lock looking icon, if you click that it will give you a notice thing and after you click "Got it!" You can put in the key and the value. For this instance the key would be "TOKEN" and the value would be the token you copied from the bot. Once you've done that, you scroll down and click the first insert button where it says "import os", then click the second insert button where it says my_secret = [the token the bot has], you can change where you want the lines of code to make it more organized :)

replies.text: By the way the "l"s I added represent the lines, they are not apart of the actual thing

replies.author: Seraphim
replies.text:
​@User_Red_Dot Took me a while to figure it out too so don't worry!  I solved it by understanding what was wrong, basically it means that "await" is outside of the "async" thing.  

 @client.event
 async def on_message(message):
 l  if message.author == client.user:
 l  l  return
 l 
 l  if message.content.startswith('Hello'):
 l  l await message.channel.send('Hello :D!!')

The lines indicate if the code is in the group or not, so now the "await" is inside the async group.  When you type in the : and press enter you basically tell it that you want whatever you're currently typing in the group.  Apologies if my explanation is a little confusing, I'd be glad to try my best to walk you through it again if needed.

replies.text:
@AwesomeSikh boy 
My code

import discord
import os

client = discord.Client()

@client.event
async def on_ready():
  print('We have logged in as {0.user}'.format(client)) 

@client.event
async def on_message(message):
  if message.author == client.user:
    return

  if message.content.startswith('!hello'):
    await message.channle.send('Hello!')

my_secret = os.environ['Token']
client.run(os.environ['Token'])

Under the padlock you can use secrets. Under Key you enter the name, and under value the token. Then just press insert on both the buttons below that. and you are done

topLevelComment.author: cach dies
topLevelComment.text:
I started to code my own discord bot after seeing this vodeo and wanted to share something I learned throughout. DO NOT write your program like this. Using on_message() and .startswith() to write commands is absolutely the worst way to code a discord bot.
Discord.py has a way to actually manage commands on its own! It is much better it allows for better organization and handling, this is a good video to understand the underlying logic but do not code your bot this way. Moreover, there is a (very) new way to create commands called slash commands. These are very fancy and, while still in their infacy, will become the best way to make a discord bot in the future.

topLevelComment.author: Noobly_Darun
topLevelComment.text:
for someone who is lazy like me heres is the whole code

import discord
import os
import requests
import json
import random
from replit import db
from keep_alive import keep_alive


client = discord.Client()

sad_words = ['sad','depressed','unhappy','angry']

starter_encouragments=['cheer up','u got this']

def get_quote():
  response = requests.get("https://zenquotes.io/api/random")  
  json_data = json.loads(response.text)
  quote = json_data[0]['q']+ " -" + json_data [0]['a']
  return(quote)

def update_encouragments(encouraging_messages):
  if "encouragments" in db.keys():
   encouragments =db["encouragments"]
   encouragments.append(encouraging_messages)
   db["encouragments"] = encouragments
  else:
    db["encouragments"]=[encouraging_messages] 

def delete_encouragments(index):
  encouragments = db["encouragments"]
  if len("encouragments") >index:
    del encouragments [index]  
    db["encoragments"]= encouragments


@client.event
async def on_ready():
  print('we have logged in as  {0.user}'.format(client))

@client.event
async def on_message(message):
  if message.author == client.user:
    return


  if message.content.startswith('$inspire'):
    quote=get_quote()
    await message.channel.send(quote)

  options = starter_encouragments
  if "encouragments" in db.keys():
    options = options + db["encouragments"]


  if any(word in message.content for word in sad_words):
    quote = get_quote()
    await message.channel.send(random.choice(options))
    await message.channel.send("here is a quote for u")
    await message.channel.send(quote)
    
  if message.content.startswith('$new'):
    encouraging_messages = message.content.split('$new ',1)[1]
    update_encouragments(encouraging_messages)
    await message.channel.send ('encouragment added')

  if message.content.startswith('$del'):
    encouragments = []
    if 'encouragments' in db.keys():
      index = int(message.content.split("$del",1)[1])
      delete_encouragments(index)
      encouragments = db["encouragments"]
    await message.channel.send(encouragments)

  if message.content.startswith("$list"):
    encouragments = []
    if "encouragments" in db.keys():
      encouragments= db ["encouragments"]
    await message.channel.send(encouragments)  

keep_alive()
client.run(os.getenv('TOKEN'))

topLevelComment.author: Anand Krishna
topLevelComment.text:
Just skimmed through the video - here are a few reasons that it is a badly done tutorial:
1) Used requests library to make requests to the API. You are supposed to use the non-blocking aiohttp module for these purposes. https://discordpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq.html#what-does-blocking-mean

2) Used discord.Client throughout the video, even when the bot was centered around making commands. By now, it is common knowledge that you are supposed to be using the commands extension of discord.py and commands.Bot for this.

3) Uses the repl.it db - which will also be blocking - same as point 1. You should be using a proper database, with a proper async driver module for it.

4) Uses repl.it for hosting - this platform isn't made to be used for hosting. The fact that you have to be running a webserver continuously, just to keep the repl alive is proof enough for this. As it isn't built to be a host, it works as a rather poor host at that. (I can excuse this though, not wanting to pay for a host is fine, but definitely wouldn't recommend this.)

To any beginners seeing this, discord.py isn't a beginner's library. You should have at least some knowledge of python beforehand, at least till OOP (classes). If you don't, go now, learn it, and then come back to this. I spend time answering questions in a support server, and you will not believe how many beginners come asking the most basic of questions, because they didn't learn python first. Moreover, don't follow youtube tutorials like this one - the large majority of them are bad. Documentation is your best friend (these videos will become outdated as the library updates, but the docs will always give you the right info).

topLevelComment.author: Suraj
topLevelComment.text:
As a person who used this library for more than 1 year

Everything said in this video is done in such a bad practice
really expected something better than this 
everything wrong with this 

- repl.it , your token is visible to everyone 
- using discord.Client instead of discord.ext.commands.Bot
- using a on_message event instead of using commands extension provided with commands.Bot
- Using of json to store some critical data 
- Using requests as it blocks the whole code while it waits for the reply from said url.

I would recommend seeing the basic bot example from git repo as it is using a proper way of doing stuff
If you need any help then join the discord server listed in the docs.

topLevelComment.author: SirSnipes
topLevelComment.text:
Note! 
If you're having issues creating the initial bot, for example nothing showing on startup. Go through this checklist. 
1) Check the indentation of the code. I had mine on the scope of the async event. It should be indented at the global level.
2) The line that said 'client.run(os.getenv('TOKEN'))' was not working properly. I had to move development to my desktop. Try hard-coding your key temporarily until you can find another solution. 
3) Make sure all of your changes are saved for the bot on discord dev page.

topLevelComment.author: Raoul1808
topLevelComment.text: Just letting you know there is an even simpler way of handling commands on discord.py rather than checking every single message (see discord.ext.commands in the discord.py api reference)🙃

replies.author: Raoul1808
replies.text:
Basically you add a reference to another part of the library, change the client object and then create async functions tagged as commands. Here are the steps:
- Import the command handler (add this at the top of the file)
from discord.ext import commands

- Create a bot object (you can replace the discord.Client() call)
client = commands.Bot(command_prefix=<your prefix>)

- Create a command
@client.command()
async def your_command_name(ctx, <arguments>):
    . . .

If you have a on_message event, you have to add a line at the end for the commands to work:
await client.process_commands(message)


And that’s it! Once you have defined a few commands, you can just run the bot and call it with the prefix you defined, it’ll automatically detect the command and run it.

(Note: in this case, to send messages you’ll have to use « await ctx.send(. . .) »)

I also highly recommend you check the documentation. It’s well written and helped me a lot making interactive minesweeper and a ton of other stuff 😄

topLevelComment.text: Hey, there's a lot of things wrong with this tutorial. First of all, you should be using discord.ext.commands.Bot instead of discord.Client which allows you to use @client.command(), and not a massive wall of ifs (which by the way should be if, elif, elif etc.). This code would be very hard to maintain and putting everything is a very very bad idea. You should really look into using Cogs.

replies.author: MysticalC9000
replies.text:
For what are you using the strip() method? I didn't see it used in the entire section of the timestamp you gave me. Maybe go through that part and check whether you've not made a typo in the code?

Edit : Just in case I'm being blind and the strip() method is being used somewhere, a NoneType Error comes up when the variable you're using to denote the string doesn't have any information. So if you are using strip() somewhere, make sure whatever you are 'stripping' is storing information first. For eg- if you want to strip a variable 'msg' [  msg.strip() ], make sure the 'msg' variable actually has a string, which you can check by doing print(msg).

topLevelComment.author: _ Ahn
topLevelComment.text:
At 37:49, he types "delete_encouragment(index)" The E after G is missing. And at 46:22, he types "delete_encouragment(index)" 
- This has to be "_encouragment" since the previous one was "_encouragment" or a red underline will appear, saying it's undefined and the "$del 0" won't WORK. 

Chances are that you might spell "_encouragment" correctly the next time, that's what happened to me and caused frustration.

topLevelComment.author: Holof
topLevelComment.text: There's soooo much wrong with this tutorial, please don't follow it. Look into the official documentation and follow the guide on how to set up a basic bot, it's gonna be a nightmare to maintain code that's done like this.

replies.author: Despa Cito

replies.author: Holof
replies.text: @Nuhjeea i forgot to add: the only thing that i would change about this tutorial, nevermind if it was just for me or if wanted to do something neater, is to actually use the command decorators ('@bot.command()') for commands. Not just putting every single command on the on_message event.

replies.author: Holof
replies.text: @Nuhjeea if you just want to make something quick that's just for you, this should work, but if you want to make something that's easier to maintain and neater you should go for something closer to what the official repo shows. Learn about how to work with object oriented programming, databases and threading if you're planning on doing this for a bot that other people will use. Be responsible with your code!

replies.author: Swarnim Yamdagni
replies.text:
@Sarguhl  I have fixed it after trying for 3 hours. 
TheIr was no error in the console upon running.
The @client.command() just didn't work for some reason. I set the prefix as + and wrote a command. But when I put that in the discord it wouldn't give out any output, there was no error in the console either. 
Turns out that for some reason, adding this:
@client.event
async def on_message(message):
       message.author==client.user:
               return

Was what was preventing it. I removed that and it all worked again

topLevelComment.text: Write a C++ program for maintaining the library record of 100 books.
